channel.title: 32 bit or 64 bit
channel.description:
How would I determine whether the bit count of the computer that a Java application is running on is 32 or 64 bit?
Thanks.

item.title: 32 bit or 64 bit
item.dc:creator: @chri5 chri5
item.description:
@chri5 wrote:

[quote=“R3volution`, post:12, topic:330278”][quote author=chri5 link=topic=426658.msg3138461#msg3138461 date=1267273202]

System.getProperty("os.arch");

https://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/lang/management/OperatingSystemMXBean.html#getArch()

http://sigar.hyperic.com/ (Although this uses native code and is probably too bulky)
[/quote]

i beleive the bank covered that already.[/quote]
My mistake, the only option is an external library/JNI. I use Sigar (the 3rd option/2nd link), and it works well, and pre-compiled for many OS architecture combinations.

Read full topic

item.title: 32 bit or 64 bit
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

abraham clearly doesn’t understand that there is no such thing as a type at run-time. it’s only there in source files so that the compiler knows how much memory to allocate.

Read full topic

item.title: 32 bit or 64 bit
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

uhhhhhhhhhhhh sizeof isn’t a function… it’s an operator.

Read full topic

item.title: 32 bit or 64 bit
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:6, topic:330278”][quote author=abraham2119 link=topic=426658.msg3136262#msg3136262 date=1266987544]
the bank, once you know the JVM’s architecture, you don’t need to check if it’s a WOW64 process. As for the OP, simply have a native function (as the bank suggested) that returns ‘sizeof(int)’, which will simply return the size of each of the processor’s registers (4 (bytes) on 32-bit and 8 (bytes) on 64-bit).
[/quote]sizeof is replaced by the value at compile time[/quote]Oh, I wasn’t aware of that. Can you invoke it dynamically through something like ‘GetProcAddress’, or not?

Read full topic

item.title: 32 bit or 64 bit
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

When inside a java app, why do you care what the underlying OS architecture is, when all that matters to you is whether the VM is 32 or 64 bit? Unless it is just an exercise or something.

Read full topic

As for the OP, simply have a native function (as the bank suggested) that returns ‘sizeof(int)’, which will simply return the size of each of the processor’s registers (4 (bytes) on 32-bit and 8 (bytes) on 64-bit).[/quote]sizeof is replaced by the value at compile time

item.title: 32 bit or 64 bit

item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

the bank, once you know the JVM’s architecture, you don’t need to check if it’s a WOW64 process. As for the OP, simply have a native function (as the bank suggested) that returns ‘sizeof(int)’, which will simply return the size of each of the processor’s registers (4 (bytes) on 32-bit and 8 (bytes) on 64-bit).

item.title: 32 bit or 64 bit
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

http://mark.koli.ch/2009/10/reliably-checking-os-bitness-32-or-64-bit-on-windows-with-a-tiny-c-app.html

What Nueb posted, aswell as os.arch, will check whether the installed JRE is 32 or 64 bit, however the underlying operating system “bitness” can only be found using native code found in that article, and calling it with JNI.

Read full topic

item.title: 32 bit or 64 bit
item.dc:creator: @R3volution1 R3volution`
item.description:
@R3volution1 wrote:

Nueb35:

System.getProperty("sun.arch.data.model");

Primadude, if your checking against the JVM being either 32/64 bit then what Nueb35 posted is correct, however im not sure whether your trying to check the JVM or processor. If its the processor that obviously wont work.

Read full topic
